001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * A group of similar methods for getting hashes of points based on long coordinates in 2, 3, 4, or 6 dimensions and
005 * a long for state; like {@link PointHash} but faster and maybe not as high-quality. This implementation has
006 * high enough quality to be useful as a source of random numbers based on positions, but would likely not be a good
007 * option in a hash table (or at least not as good as the tailored implementation of {@link Coord#hashCode()}, for
008 * instance). At low dimensions, this is a little faster than {@link PointHash}, but this class doesn't slow 
009 * down much at all as more dimensions are used, while PointHash and most other implementations do slow down. You
010 * can also consider {@link IntPointHash} if your input and output types are usually int, since it's even faster.
011 * <br>
012 * This implements {@link IPointHash} and has a long it uses internally for state, exposed by {@link #getState()}.
013 */
014public final class HastyPointHash extends IPointHash.LongImpl
015{
016    @Override
017    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state) {
018        return (int)hashAll(x, y, state);
019    }
020
021    @Override
022    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state) {
023        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, state);
024    }
025
026    @Override
027    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state) {
028        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, w, state);
029    }
030
031    @Override
032    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state) {
033        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, state);
034    }
035    
036    @Override
037    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state) {
038        return (int)hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, v, state);
039    }
040    
041    public long getState(){
042        return state;
043    }
044
045    /**
046     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
047     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
048     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
049     * <br>
050     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
051     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
052     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
053     * generalized ratio. See
054     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
055     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
056     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
057     * @param x x position; any long
058     * @param y y position; any long
059     * @param s the state/seed; any long
060     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
061     */
062    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long s) {
063        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
064        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
065        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
066        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
067    }
068
069    /**
070     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
071     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
072     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
073     * <br>
074     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
075     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
076     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
077     * generalized ratio. See
078     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
079     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
080     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
081     * @param x x position; any long
082     * @param y y position; any long
083     * @param z z position; any long
084     * @param s the state/seed; any long
085     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
086     */
087    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
088        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
089        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
090        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
091        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
092        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
093    }
094
095    /**
096     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
097     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
098     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
099     * <br>
100     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
101     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
102     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
103     * generalized ratio. See
104     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
105     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
106     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
107     * @param x x position; any long
108     * @param y y position; any long
109     * @param z z position; any long
110     * @param w w position; any long
111     * @param s the state; any long
112     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
113     */
114    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
115        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
116        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;
117        y += z * 0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL;
118        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;
119        s += x * 0x881403B9339BD42DL;
120        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
121    }
122
123    /**
124     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 5D point (x, y, z, w, and u are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
125     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
126     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
127     * <br>
128     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
129     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
130     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
131     * generalized ratio. See
132     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
133     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
134     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
135     * @param x x position; any long
136     * @param y y position; any long
137     * @param z z position; any long
138     * @param w w position; any long
139     * @param u u position; any long
140     * @param s the state; any long
141     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state
142     */
143    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long s) {
144        u += s * 0xE60E2B722B53AEEBL;
145        w += u * 0xCEBD76D9EDB6A8EFL;
146        z += w * 0xB9C9AA3A51D00B65L;
147        y += z * 0xA6F5777F6F88983FL;
148        x += y * 0x9609C71EB7D03F7BL;
149        s += x * 0x86D516E50B04AB1BL;
150        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
151    }
152
153    /**
154     * Gets a 64-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
155     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
156     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
157     * <br>
158     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
159     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
160     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
161     * generalized ratio. See
162     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
163     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
164     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
165     * @param x x position; any long
166     * @param y y position; any long
167     * @param z z position; any long
168     * @param w w position; any long
169     * @param u u position; any long
170     * @param v v position; any long
171     * @param s the state; any long
172     * @return 64-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
173     */
174    public static long hashAll(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
175        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
176        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
177        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
178        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
179        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
180        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
181        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
182        return ((s = (s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) ^ s >>> 25);
183    }
184    /**
185     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
186     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
187     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
188     * <br>
189     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
190     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
191     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
192     * generalized ratio. See
193     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
194     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
195     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
196     * @param x x position; any long
197     * @param y y position; any long
198     * @param s the state/seed; any long
199     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
200     */
201    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long s) {
202        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
203        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
204        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
205        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
206    }
207
208    /**
209     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
210     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
211     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
212     * <br>
213     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
214     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
215     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
216     * generalized ratio. See
217     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
218     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
219     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
220     * @param x x position; any long
221     * @param y y position; any long
222     * @param z z position; any long
223     * @param s the state/seed; any long
224     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
225     */
226    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
227        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
228        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
229        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
230        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
231        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
232    }

234    /**
235     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
236     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
237     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
238     * <br>
239     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
240     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
241     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
242     * generalized ratio. See
243     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
244     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
245     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
246     * @param x x position; any long
247     * @param y y position; any long
248     * @param z z position; any long
249     * @param w w position; any long
250     * @param s the state; any long
251     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
252     */
253    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
254        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
255        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;

257        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;

259        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
260    }

263    /**
264     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 5D point (x, y, z, w, and u are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
265     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
266     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
267     * <br>
268     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
269     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
270     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
271     * generalized ratio. See
272     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
273     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
274     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
275     * @param x x position; any long
276     * @param y y position; any long
277     * @param z z position; any long
278     * @param w w position; any long
279     * @param u u position; any long
280     * @param s the state; any long
281     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state
282     */
283    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long s) {
284        u += s * 0xE60E2B722B53AEEBL;
285        w += u * 0xCEBD76D9EDB6A8EFL;
286        z += w * 0xB9C9AA3A51D00B65L;
287        y += z * 0xA6F5777F6F88983FL;
288        x += y * 0x9609C71EB7D03F7BL;
289        s += x * 0x86D516E50B04AB1BL;
290        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
291    }

293    /**
294     * Gets an 8-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
295     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
296     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
297     * <br>
298     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
299     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
300     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
301     * generalized ratio. See
302     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
303     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
304     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
305     * @param x x position; any long
306     * @param y y position; any long
307     * @param z z position; any long
308     * @param w w position; any long
309     * @param u u position; any long
310     * @param v v position; any long
311     * @param s the state; any long
312     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
313     */
314    public static int hash256(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
315        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
316        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
317        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
318        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
319        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
320        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
321        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
322        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 56);
323    }
324    /**
325     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
326     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
327     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
328     * <br>
329     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
330     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
331     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
332     * generalized ratio. See
333     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
334     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
335     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
336     * @param x x position; any long
337     * @param y y position; any long
338     * @param s the state/seed; any long
339     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
340     */
341    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long s) {
342        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
343        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
344        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
345        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
346    }

348    /**
349     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
350     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
351     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
352     * <br>
353     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
354     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
355     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
356     * generalized ratio. See
357     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
358     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
359     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
360     * @param x x position; any long
361     * @param y y position; any long
362     * @param z z position; any long
363     * @param s the state/seed; any long
364     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
365     */
366    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
367        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
368        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
369        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
370        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
371        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
372    }

374    /**
375     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
376     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
377     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
378     * <br>
379     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
380     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
381     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
382     * generalized ratio. See
383     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
384     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
385     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
386     * @param x x position; any long
387     * @param y y position; any long
388     * @param z z position; any long
389     * @param w w position; any long
390     * @param s the state; any long
391     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
392     */
393    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
394        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
395        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;
396        y += z * 0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL;
397        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;
398        s += x * 0x881403B9339BD42DL;
399        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
400    }
401
402    /**
403     * Gets a 5-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
404     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
405     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
406     * <br>
407     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
408     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
409     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
410     * generalized ratio. See
411     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
412     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
413     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
414     * @param x x position; any long
415     * @param y y position; any long
416     * @param z z position; any long
417     * @param w w position; any long
418     * @param u u position; any long
419     * @param v v position; any long
420     * @param s the state; any long
421     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
422     */
423    public static int hash32(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
424        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
425        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
426        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
427        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
428        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
429        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
430        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
431        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 59);
432    }
433    
434    /**
435     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 2D point (x and y are both longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
436     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
437     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
438     * <br>
439     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
440     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
441     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
442     * generalized ratio. See
443     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
444     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
445     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
446     * @param x x position; any long
447     * @param y y position; any long
448     * @param s the state/seed; any long
449     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state
450     */
451    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long s) {
452        y += s * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L;
453        x += y * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L;
454        s += x * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L;
455        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
456    }
457
458    /**
459     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 3D point (x, y, and z are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
460     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
461     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
462     * <br>
463     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
464     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
465     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
466     * generalized ratio. See
467     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
468     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
469     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
470     * @param x x position; any long
471     * @param y y position; any long
472     * @param z z position; any long
473     * @param s the state/seed; any long
474     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state
475     */
476    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long z, long s) {
477        z += s * 0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L;
478        y += z * 0xBBE0563303A4615FL;
479        x += y * 0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L;
480        s += x * 0x89E182857D9ED689L;
481        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
482    }
483
484    /**
485     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 4D point (x, y, z, and w are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This point
486     * hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
487     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
488     * <br>
489     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
490     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
491     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
492     * generalized ratio. See
493     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
494     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
495     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
496     * @param x x position; any long
497     * @param y y position; any long
498     * @param z z position; any long
499     * @param w w position; any long
500     * @param s the state; any long
501     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state
502     */
503    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long z, long w, long s) {
504        w += s * 0xE19B01AA9D42C633L;
505        z += w * 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L;
506        y += z * 0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL;
507        x += y * 0x9A69443F36F710E7L;
508        s += x * 0x881403B9339BD42DL;
509        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
510    }
511
512    /**
513     * Gets a 6-bit point hash of a 6D point (x, y, z, w, u, and v are all longs) and a state/seed as a long. This
514     * point hash has close to the best speed of any algorithms tested, and though its quality is mediocre for
515     * traditional uses of hashing (such as hash tables), it's sufficiently random to act as a positional RNG.
516     * <br>
517     * This uses a technique related to the one used by Martin Roberts for his golden-ratio-based sub-random
518     * sequences, where each axis is multiplied by a different constant, and the choice of constants depends on the
519     * number of axes but is always related to a generalized form of golden ratios, repeatedly dividing 1.0 by the
520     * generalized ratio. See
521     * <a href="http://extremelearning.com.au/unreasonable-effectiveness-of-quasirandom-sequences/">Roberts' article</a>
522     * for some more information on how he uses this, but we do things differently because we want random-seeming
523     * results instead of separated sub-random results.
524     * @param x x position; any long
525     * @param y y position; any long
526     * @param z z position; any long
527     * @param w w position; any long
528     * @param u u position; any long
529     * @param v v position; any long
530     * @param s the state; any long
531     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state
532     */
533    public static int hash64(long x, long y, long z, long w, long u, long v, long s) {
534        v += s * 0xE95E1DD17D35800DL;
535        u += v * 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL;
536        w += u * 0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L;
537        z += w * 0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL;
538        y += z * 0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L;
539        x += y * 0x92E852C80D153DB3L;
540        s += x * 0x85EB75C3024385C3L;
541        return (int)(((s ^ s >>> 27 ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L) >>> 58);
542    }
543
544    public static int hash256_alt(final long x, final long y, final long z, final long w, final long seed) {
545        long a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
546        return (int) ((0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L
547                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * seed + x)
548                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * x + y)
549                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * y + z)
550                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * z + w)
551                + (a ^= 0x85157AF5L * w + seed)) * a >>> 56);
552    }
553
554}
